comments:
What is the "cloud"? How are software systems and components that scale to
millions of users and petabytes of data, and are "always available" built? In the modern
Internet, virtually all large Web services run atop multiple geographically distributed data
centers: Google, Yahoo, Facebook, iTunes, Amazon, eBay, Bing, Services must scale
across thousands of machines, tolerate faults, and support of concurrent requests.
Increasingly, the major providers (including Amazon, GoMicrosoft, HP, and IBM) are
looking at "hosting" third-party applications in their data centers - forming so-called
"cloud computing" services. A significant number of these services also process
"streaming" data: geocoding information from cell phones, tweets, streaming video, etc.
This course, aimed at a sophomore with exposure to basic programming within the
context of a single machine, focuses on the issues and programming models related to
such cloud and distributed data processing technologies: data partitioning, storage
schemes, stream processing, and "mostly shared-nothing" parallel algorithms.
Generally, students were pleased with the content of this course, as it covered “the
more practical aspects of computer science” and an understanding into the structure of
the internet. Many also appreciated the breadth of the course in covering “the cloud
computing world,” but others felt that this was a weakness, limiting the depth of material
learned. The assignments were a chance to apply new concepts learned, and were “tough”
and “specific.”
One student praised Professor Haeberlen for being “extremely helpful in resolving
[homework setup] issues.” However, there was “very little communication between [the
TAs] and Professor Haeberlen,” which hindered progress on the assignments and
projects.
Students agreed that the course was difficult and rigorous. It was also time
consuming, particularly because of difficulties encountered with “framework and
configuration steps” for the cloud services utilized in the assignments. For the
assignments, one student thought that they were difficult concept-wise, but “not due to
the programming.” Respondents also warned that those who came “from a very basic
CIS120-level computer science background” were at a disadvantage.
